greetings my name is michael fuller and
this brief presentation is sponsored by
archaeology now as a professional
archaeologist i live in st. Louis but
I've done decades of fieldwork in the
Middle East and Europe and North America
and I definitely know what it is to be
thirsty I want to talk about the
archaeology of thirsty camels can go
seven months without a drink but a human
will die of thirst in three to four days
so be careful out there when doing field
work early humans undoubtedly chose to
drink almost always from lakes or
Springs or rivers fresh flowing water or
still flowing water but the problem is
that water may not taste very good it
could taste fishy or it could be
polluted by people living upstream from
where you're drinking so a much better
source of drinking water is freshwater
Springs where the water literally erupts
out of the bedrock I can think of
numerous archaeological sites in the
Middle East that are directly associated
with large Springs Jericho associated
the spring called in Sultan Amman
associated with the spring called I in
Gaza and in fact 414 field seasons I
worked in Syria at a site called tel
Tuna near right next to I knew--i the
spring of Noah Springs our perennial
sometimes they go dry during the summer
and they have sometimes low amounts of
water during other seasons of the year
now 10,000 years ago people discovered
how to domesticate cattle and how to
domesticate sheep and goats and they
produced not only meat they also produce
milk and we had another way of quenching
your thirst but milk after a few days
curdles or it goes sour so you have to
milk every day if you want to have that
say quench in for your thirst now around
ten thousand years ago people were also
discovering fruit juice could be
obtained from various fruits and the
king of all fruits for giving juice is
the grape it every grape is basically
just a little bag of sugar water waiting
to quench your thirst interesting thing
about grapes is after the juice has been
pressed about three or four days
afterwards unless you can figure out how
to sterilize it and bottle it it's going
to begin to firm it it's going to begin
to change thanks to you
from grape juice into an alcoholic thing
called wine typically about 10 to 12
percent alcohol will be the end result
and you know ancient people learned
pretty quickly that not only does wine
quench your thirst and also changes your
attitude about life and how things are
going the Romans have many paintings
like one from Pompeii where it shows
little butai little Cupid like creatures
who are busily having a party drinking
wine because wine encourages one to
celebrate peace prosperity happiness and
leisure it makes those things even more
vivid to you now certain climates
certain soil types will not support
grape cultivation and people figured out
how to ferment something else they
figured out how to firm it cereal
products creating what we call beer and
in fact almost anytime beer is being
fermented you'll find special ceramics
sibs or you'll find ceramic jars that
have been pierced in a process of
filtering that product and here's an
example from the Indus Valley
Civilisation 4000 years ago in India of
one of these vessels associated with the
fermentation of a barley or possibly
millet and rice which were also for a
minute during that time period in the
Indus Valley now my interest in
fermentable things comes about as a
result of a discovery I made while
digging in Syria at the archaeological
site of Tel tuna near in the background
you can see the hub or River
and in the foreground you can see a
monastery workshop that included to
crushing basins and to fermentation vats
for making wine now how do we know all
this we were excavating in the second
layer of soil below the surface called
locust tube in square 72 area 10 62
centimeters below the surface yes
archaeology is very precise we found a
large broken wine jar where a monk had
made a list of the types of wine he was
producing he wrote down the types of
wine in the quantities in Aramaic a very
ancient Semitic language and what we
could learn was that there was table
wine there was communion wine you'd only
called why more precious than gold and
then there was two medicinal wines a
wine for the blue disease and a wine for
the hacking cause as we continue to
excavate in that area we actually found
the to crushing basins where the wine
grapes would be stomped and we found two
very large fermentation vats where over
hundreds of gallons of the juice would
be held until they had undergone an
initial fermentation in fact the
crushing Basin would be quite large
probably at least three or four men some
of the monks maybe some of the men hired
by the monastery would stomp on the
grapes with the juice then flowing into
the large collection VAT the bottom of
each collection that actually had a
craft built into it to catch some of the
grape seeds that might have escaped
during the stomping process and as we
are cleaning out the trap we were
surprised to find a treasure not out of
gold not out of silver but out of clay
we found a pottery carafe the vessel
that had been used to dip the wine out
of that Basin which had broken and been
allowed to fall down in the trap and
waited for us to find during our last
season of excavation
we found only the wine carafe we found
many of the large wine storage jars
probably about a week after stomping on
the grapes and while the initial
fermentation was going they would bucket
the wine into large pottery jars the
size of oil drums we found over a dozen
of these each one of those jars was
distinctly decorated with patterns of
finger swirls to my mind that's probably
how the ancient wine maker had kept
track of either what part of the
vineyard the grapes had come from or
what part of the season the grapes have
been harvested in knowing that the later
in the season that you harvest the
grapes the higher the sugar content is
meaning the more alcohol the wine could
produce but also the sweeter the wine
would be when the fermentation was over
as archaeologists we photographed these
we make drawings of these and they all

where I had left them I told you we
found lots of really large jars those
was that was the wine being served day
